choices.text:
the civil war defeat in 2009, ending a brutal conflict of nearly 30 years. This conflict devastated the North and East of the country. The population that was affected by this conflict dealt with the trauma of the war in different ways. Some people escaped the conflict, came to tearthedoll’s place and sadly there is no validation and acceptance of their story. Others decided that they needed to take revenge for their deserved loss. The continuing generational trauma and the ongoing war between two major political parties adds to the chains of trauma lost and forgotten stories.

Following my inquiry with the community of tearthedoll’s country, I was invited to share my paintings in their war museum. Playing with the ephemeral nature of plasters and clay, I draped and reconstructed the oldest stones of the country to give new meaning and connection to the history that was wrapped in the layers of flood and typhoon which the country is well known for. I found vernacular beauty through these reclaimed stones and gave voice to a country, whose culture and language has been silenced and has probably forgotten. Part of this work takes the clear colour palate of plasters, which is used to give permanence to a stain. I proceeded with stains of other colours on top to show the conceptual work of remembering.

Participants in this program will be greeted by Tea, cookies and music as well as instruction on the basics of ceramics: reading a ceramic plan, inspecting for underfired or overfired work, methods of glazing
